choices.B: The MOA should address the client SLA in relation to reporting results to regulatory authorities, including issuing banks for organizations that process cardholder data.
choices.D: The exploitation standards should be addressed in the rules of engagement to ensure both parties are aware of the depth of exploitation that will be attempted by penetration testers.
choices.C: The rules of engagement should include detailed results of the penetration scan, including all findings, as well as designation of whether vulnerabilities identified during the scanning phases are found to be exploitable during the penetration test.
choices.A: The scope of the penetration test should be included in the MOA to ensure penetration testing is conducted against only specifically authorized network resources.

discussion.content:
Yeah, rules of engagement should only contain details on how the pentest would be done. There's a different document for the findings of the scan/test.
I think this is D.
A - wrong as the scope should be included in Rules of Engagement and not in MOA.
B - not sure?
C - as discussed above
Why would C be the answer? Why would results be included in the rules of engagement, before "engagement" even begins? More poor wording on the end of CompTIA
This question is on the exam.

A. The scope is always part of the ROE document. In addition, a MOU is not legally binding where as a ROE is.
B. An SLA is a completely different document and is also legally binding. It's not part of MOU.
C. The ROE does define communication and reporting expectations, but those reports are not included in the ROE itself.
D. Exploitation -among other things - is part of the ROE. D is the right answer.
C relates to the findings of the scan/test which shouldnt be found in rules of engagement? Am i missing something here?
The answer should be D. The ROE addresses the pen test itself on what network, data, and regulatory compliance will be affected.

questions.question_text: An organization is performing vendor selection activities for penetration testing, and a security analyst is reviewing the MOA and rules of engagement, which were supplied with proposals. Which of the following should the analyst expect will be included in the documents and why?

discussion.content: Cloud providers won't disclose any information about other clients

comments.content: You can't just engage a third party vendor to perform pen-test on a cloud service provider's network. You'll need to seek for approval from the cloud service provider. So 'A' is definitely out.

discussion.content:
"... the site begins to redirect to a competitor's landing page. " that means the clients are willingly going to the site and then the website redirect them to the competitor's. 

Nothing to do with the DNS, so the A is the answer
This question was on the exam (october-2020)
Shouldn't this be C?

comments.content: First part of C is good. Second part, not too sure. So would have to chose B
Isn't this a typical example of DNS poisoning?

choices.B: Check DNS records to ensure Cname or alias records are in place for the subdomain
choices.A: Engage a third party to provide penetration testing services to see if an exploit can be found
choices.D: Check the DNS records to ensure a correct MX record is established for the subdomain
choices.C: Query the cloud provider to determine the nature of the DNS attack and find out which other clients are affected

questions.question_text: A manufacturing company has decided to participate in direct sales of its products to consumers. The company decides to use a subdomain of its main site with its existing cloud service provider as the portal for e-commerce. After launch, the site is stable and functions properly, but after a robust day of sales, the site begins to redirect to a competitor's landing page. Which of the following actions should the company's security team take to determine the cause of the issue and minimize the scope of impact?

Is this really brute force? Because the timings of login attempts doesn't look like a brute force has occurred from that host. 

I believe the user has forgotten his password.
It should be a forgotten password, not a brute force

Please re-look the snippet

It says "Invalid User" - If user knows the username and forotton password, it should indicate incorrect password attempt. But in here someone keep on attempting to breach the system by "root" with multiple attempts, Clear Brute Force

discussion.content: This question was on the exam (october-2020)
nmap -sV <ip_address>
I'm going to assume that this question is missing an answer: nmap -sV
It should be V instead of v which stands for verbose

questions.question_text: A company requests a security assessment of its network. Permission is given, but no details are provided. It is discovered that the company has a web presence, and the company's IP address is 70.182.11.4. Which of the following Nmap commands would reveal common open ports and their versions?

An analyst wants to use a command line tool to identify open ports and running services on a host along with the application that is associated with those services and port. Which of the following should the analyst use?

discussion.content: The correct answer is NMAP

comments.content: Could you shed some light on this? Why are you so certain?

discussion.content: Nmap is used to discover hosts and services on a computer network by sending packets
I chose Nmap and got it wrong with a Prof. Netstat is right

netstat -tulnp -> last column is PID/Program name
nmap -sV -> third column is SERVICE, fourth column is VERSION
VERSION will describe the applications associated with the service.
Answer: D. nmap
NMAP is the answer is used to scan devices running on the system, also checking services and ports which they are being run from.

netstat -b 
"Displays the executable involved in creating each connection or listening port. In some cases well-known executables host multiple independent components, and in these cases the sequence of components involved in creating the connection or listening port is displayed. In this case the executable name is in [] at the bottom, on top is the component it called, and so forth until TCP/IP was reached."

I don't believe NMAP can enumerate the application that created the connection. And there is no reason to assume this is being done remotely.
Nestat- Keyphrase; 'Running Services' nmap wont be able to tell what services are currently running on the host
Which CLI can be used to achieve the purpose in the question?

Nmap sends specially crafted packets to the target host(s) and then analyzes the responses to determine the open ports and services running on those hosts. In addition, nmap can determine the versions of the applications being used on those ports and services. Nmap is a command-line tool for use on Linux, Windows, and macOS systems. The netstat (network statistics) tool is a command-line utility that displays network connections for both incoming and outgoing TCP packets, routing tables, and a number of network interface and network protocol statistics, but it cannot be used to identify open ports and services on a host with their version numbers.

NMAP Version Detection can be used to find applications
https://nmap.org/book/solution-find-open-port.html

NMAP seems to be the correct answer. Netstat highlights the PID and not the applications.

"Nmap, short for Network Mapper, is a free, open-source tool for vulnerability scanning and network discovery. Network administrators use Nmap to identify what devices are running on their systems, discovering hosts that are available and the services they offer, finding open ports and detecting security risks"

The answer is NMAP...

comments.content: but how about the applications associated with those services? NMAP can not detect applications

discussion.content: Netstat is the answer https://www.getfilecloud.com/blog/2016/05/how-to-find-what-application-is-listening-on-a-tcpip-port-in-windows-using-netstat/#.XxRBb-wpC9c
My vote is on C, netstat. We're talking about "applications" assigned to those ports and services. There is no way of doing that with NMAP.
https://techtalk.gfi.com/scanning-open-ports-in-windows-part-3-nmap/

comments.content: With this in mind, since they are looking for the "BEST" answer, NMAP can be used in both cases.

But can you find specific information about the applications/services linked to each port with NMAP? You can find SOME information with NMAP, surely, but not as much detail as NETSTAT. I'm a bit confused here. "Open ports" makes me believe it should be NMAP, but then throw in "Application" in the mix, and I feel like that's more closely related to NETSTAT... .

discussion.content: This is another one of those questions where I feel more info is needed. Do we have direct access to the host? Or is this to be done remotely... both NMAP and netstat fit the description here....

comments.content: You're right. NMAP is ran via command line. I realized that the next day and forgot to correct myself.
NMAP can also be run on a Linux command line. But, even then, it won’t show the running applications. So you’re still right, Netstat is correct.

discussion.content: COMMAND LINE tool.... netstat

C is correct. Netstat would be the more useful command for an analyst with full access to the host system. Netstat provides more detailed information about open services and ports. Nmap would be for discovering remote systems and ports, but it may not find as much information as the host system would provide through netstat.
Correct. Netstat can report the application associated with the open port as well.
